"The data would be obtained from an online database such as Spotify does it (Unfortunately I wasn't able to manage it to work YET).
Users can play and stop the music, can put it onto the favourites list and can get detailed information about each song.
The Home button takes the user back to this screen!
Infos can be found at the bottom of the activities!

The music-loving inhabitants of Pepperland are under siege by the Blue Meanies, a nasty group of music-hating creatures. The Lord Mayor of Pepperland (Dick Emery) dispatches sailor Old Fred (Lance Percival) to Liverpool, England, where he is to recruit the help of the Beatles (John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison, Ringo Starr). The sympathetic Beatles ride a yellow submarine to the occupied Pepperland, where the Blue Meanies have no chance against the Fab Four's groovy tunes.

Release date: August 20, 1970
Directors: George Dunning, Al Brodax, Robert Balser, Jack Stokes
Characters: Jeremy Hilary Boob, Ph.D, Chief Blue Meanie, Old Fred, Lord Mayor, Max, Ringo, George, Paul, John Lennon

A Hard Day's Night is the third studio album by the English rock band the Beatles, released on 10 July 1964, with side one containing songs from the soundtrack to their film A Hard Day's Night.

Release date: June 26, 1964
Label: United Artists Records

"Twist and Shout" is a 1961 song written by Phil Medley and Bert Berns (later credited as "Bert Russell"). The song was originally recorded by The Top Notes. It first became a chart hit as a cover single by the Isley Brothers in 1962. The song has since been covered by several artists, including the Beatles on their first album Please Please Me (1963), as well as the Tremeloes in 1962 and the Who in 1970 and 1984.

Released 1961
Writer(s): Bert Berns, Phil Medley
Producer(s): Phil Spector

Let It Be is the twelfth and final studio album by the English rock band the Beatles. It was released on 8 May 1970, almost a month after the group\'s break-up. Like most of the band\'s previous releases, it was a number one album in many countries, including both the US and the UK, and was released in tandem with the motion picture of the same name.\n\nReleased:8 May 1970 (UK), 18 May 1970 (US)

On this screen the user can play and stop the music and can add or delete to/from the favourites list..
Every hit on play button will increase the number of hits.
As the music player is declared empty first and then the path for the media is assigned to it, it can play only 1 song at a time. Unfortunately I couldn't manage to set all the other song's play button back to default if a song is played.
Another thing is in progress to store hits and isFavourited values with sharedPreferences...

On this screen used will see all the songs which was added to the list (But it still needs sharedPreferences).\nAnother function would be great to be done is making new playlists. Just like in Spotify.
On the detailed info screen user can read some info about the song.\n It would be nice to connect the seek bar with the songs process...\nPrevious, Play, Stop and next buttons are working also.
